title: What does it mean when it says "Declaration of Good Faith"?
question: Allegation re current liabilities of the estate & how much will be paid, what is the meaning of that when it comes to Probate? This was in the Examiner notes on the court website?
answers: In addition to the possibility offered by Ms. James, some courts want a good faith declaration regarding the debts and liabilities when an out of state representative is being appointed. This is because bond can be required, even if a will waives bond, when the personal representative does not reside in California. In that situation, the bond is for the protection of the creditors.

The court wants to know what the liabilities of the estate are. It sounds like the estate is insolvent? If not a verified supplement should be filed listing the liabilities and stating they have all (or will all) be paid. If there is not enough money to pay all of the liabilities, state which ones and in what portion they will be paid.

This post is too cryptic to lend it self to posting a response. What do you mean by Examiner notes? I don't know what document you are referring to. What was it that was filed to which maybe a probate attorney was responding?
